CatDescriptText: Mr. James Wade, truck driver, Beltzhoover and Miss Elizabeth Pearson, housewife, Uptown, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, February 3, 1962, pg. 7 with question: "Do you think that in custody cases a child should be awarded to the mother, even though she may be of questionable background?...Or do you think they should be placed in a foster home, with visiting privileges being granted to the parent?" Mr. Wade's answer reads: "I don't believe any child should be placed into a foster home.  In a few cases, they may be better off in a foster home.  But in the majority of cases, the child or children is better off with the mother."  Ms. Pearson's answer reads: "If they know definitely that the background of the mother is not good they should put the child into a foster home or find a better home in some way."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of James Wade wearing hat, moustache, and coat with square buttons, standing in front of building; Portrait of Elizabeth Mae Pearson Balilem wearing fur hat, and dark coat with fur collar, holding paper bag, standing in front of building
